Blog.post: The car left the road so suddenly I didn’t have time to react. You think that you will be able to do something in that instant. I’ve done enough motorway driving to have considered the options as triplex shatters all around, your glasses fly off, you tuck your feet under you, you step from the vehicle, Chuck Jones like at the moment of impact, unscathed to view the un-toyota shaped corrola. “bloody hell that was close” you say to your fellow accidentees, who similarly have all escaped. As I say, lots of mileage. Back-ache, boredom, and shattered ankles. You may detect in me a tendency towards the morbid. I don’t apologise for this it’s not my fault. Every peer group has its rites of passage. Hypnogogically speaking horror features strongly. Influenced at an early age by the luridity of The Encyclopedia of Horror films, a much loved and thumbed volume in the school library. And what was that series on ITV on Saturday nights. Not Tales of the Unexpected. Wasn’t it just called “Thriller”. Now my darkest fears approach. Diana Dors as a witch, postcard picturesque Sussex Villages with their hedgerows concealing untold menace and people bricked up in chimneys ‘cos they knew too much or not enough. It was a feature of those longed for weekends. An escape from the horrors of school to the horrors of the imagination. A man haunted by the number of the beast, reoccurring everywhere he looked. Phone numbers, car registrations, house numbers. A woman tormented by visitations, mysterious phone calls, threatening noises in the seeming banality of her sunny flat. Late night lonely paranoia brought out into the daylight which would normally banish the irrational. These images feed my fears, the laws of physics suddenly ruptured as a screaming dervish, all rotting flesh and fingernails rends apart the fabric of space time to rip me to shreds, suck out my soul as it screams an eternity of agony and blood. Even now as a so called adult, late night lonliness instils these sensations. Every creak of this Victorian terraced house a message from the underworld. We’re coming to get you, to strap you down on our obscene torture table and commit unspeakable acts of vivisection as you observe the details of our acts in extreme close-up longing for death but unable to make that transition.

That’s really when the panic attacks started in earnest. Not immediately after the old mans G3 but close enough for me to feel his fear irradiating me. After they moved to B******. After the bypass operation and his fear sharpend. Doubtless distressing. But traumatic also for those around him. Not stressfull in a Normandy landing Houston we have a problem kind of way. You and I aren’t trained to kill or build an oxygen release valve out of available components. The only available components we have are our emotions. And , if you don’t know how or when to express those intense feelings of guilt, fear, anger… well, you're fucked. We’re all fucked. Same old story, ce la vie, que sera sera, plus ca change… nothing new under the sun. If it is cancer wouldn’t there be other symptoms? Loss of appetite, nausea, bleeding, contutions. Is my tongue feeling funny ‘cos that microwaved chicken chow main… Always trying to read the signs. For best results cook from frozen. Well I’m not very warm so I’ll just get on with it. 850 watts for six minutes. Is this what mobile phones are doing to our heads forming a crust on the grey matter. Into the treeline now and “crack” that is the noise my forehead makes when I hit it against an overhanging branch. CRACK. I clutch the damage and it’s warm and wet. Great now I’m bleeding, just what I need what with the car going off the road like that the front wheels just seeming to slide out from under me the buzzing getting louder and closer. I think I’ve got cancer. I’ll roll a cigarette. The big Casino. The oncological nightmare. Hushed voices and magnetic resonance. Flowers and needles. Deeply inhaling Duma halftsware shag he continues. ***s mom died of it, of the throat. Silk Cut I believe. She was a lovely woman. Sausage and mash cartwheels and grated apple sandwiches. ***s sister S** was dads nurse when he was in hospital. Grade three myocardial infarction. The doctor insisted that it was indigestion so he went back to bed and it just got worse. So my brother called the doctor back and insisted that the old man be carted off to hospital. Pronto. What would the father have done without the son? What would the son be without the father?

So here we all are, trying to find some justification in our lives. Through material possesions, with sex and pretend sex and swatting flies and art. We look harder and harder on an ever diminishing/expanding scale in and out to the infinitely small and the infinitely humungus. Brobdignagian and Lilliputian. Balance is all. A means to prove to the world and to the self that one exsists. Touch me feel me kiss me kill me suck me fuck me. Where do I start, where do I begin. You know what they always say… I’m lost on a heath, well I assume it’s a heath. The clumpy grass suggests as much. And, I assume that I’m lost. Because there’s something I can’t quite figure out. I know who I am, I know what year it is, and the name of our current Prime Minister. All that doctor patient kind of stuff. So it’s not amnesia. But I can’t quite grasp how I came to be in this place as oppose to where I was. What! Hey! Duh! It’s getting dark and it’s starting to rain. And now, having said what I just said I seem to have been stumbling around in this twilight for some time. Or, no time at all. Quite some time. Quite. And there’s a light. Just up ahead. I’ve just noticed it. It’s flickering so it must be behind or in amongst some trees. It’s difficult to tell now it’s getting darker and the rain as it spatters my specs is multiplying the growing point of light into firework starbursts. The ground is uneven making me miss my footing and occassionally splodging into a boggy bit. And I forgot to mention the smell. Faint but distinct. And the noise, just beyond the sighing of the wind. Once again barely pereceptable but unmistakably…there.
